section.title: Inversion after negative adverbs
section.sectiontitle: We use inversion to emphasise the adverbial phrase in a sentence. Inversion is usually used in more formal or literary texts. The form is negative adverb + auxiliary verb + subject. Note: the word order is the same as the question form.
section.text1: Did she look up from her book?
section.text1a: Not once did she look up from her book.
section.text2: Do we rely on scientists to provide answers?
section.text2a: No longer do we rely on scientists to provide answers.
section.sectiontitle2: We do not use auxiliary verbs when the main verb is the verb to be or a modal verb.
section.text3a: Not only is he a brilliant mathmatician, but he knows how to teach.

section.title: Inversion after negative adverbs
section.sectiontitle: Inversion can be used after restrictive words like never, rarely, little, hardly, etc.
section.text1a: Never before had he seen such a beautiful vase.
section.text2a: Rarely did he attempt to socialise.
section.sectiontitle2: We also use inversion with phrases beginning with only. These emphasise the first clause.
section.text3a: Only now do they realise what is going on.
section.text4a: Only when I heard her speak did I remember her.

section.title: Inversion after negative adverbs
section.sectiontitle: We use no way + inversion to show that something is impossible or that the speaker doesn't want to do something. This is informal.
section.text1a: No way would I do a bungee jump!
